<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 234, 293]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/43  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 242, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 907, 319]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 880, 648]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 216, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 696, 732, 728]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A box of mass \(5\mathrm{kg}\) is pulled at a constant speed a distance of \(15\mathrm{m}\) up a rough plane inclined at an angle of \(20^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The box moves along a line of greatest slope against a frictional force of \(40\mathrm{N}\). The force pulling the box is parallel to the line of greatest slope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 445, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the work done against friction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 344, 143, 363]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 344, 636, 363]]<|/det|>
Find the change in gravitational potential energy of the box.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 344, 920, 363]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 715, 143, 733]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 715, 482, 733]]<|/det|>
Find the work done by the pulling force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 715, 920, 733]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A string is attached to a block of mass \(4\mathrm{kg}\) which rests in limiting equilibrium on a rough horizontal table. The string makes an angle of \(24^{\circ}\) above the horizontal and the tension in the string is \(30\mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 630, 139]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing all the forces acting on the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 364, 148, 382]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 364, 655, 382]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of friction between the block and the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 364, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
Two small smooth spheres \(A\) and \(B\), of equal radii and of masses \(4\mathrm{kg}\) and \(m\mathrm{kg}\) respectively, lie on a smooth horizontal plane. Initially, sphere \(B\) is at rest and \(A\) is moving towards \(B\) with speed \(6\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\). After the collision \(A\) moves with speed \(1.5\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\) and \(B\) moves with speed \(3\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 732, 156]]<|/det|>
Find the two possible values of the loss of kinetic energy due to the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 137, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves in a straight line. It starts at a point \(O\) on the line and at time \(t\) s after leaving \(O\) it has velocity \(\nu \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) , where \(\nu = 4t^{2} - 20t + 21\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 603, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(t\) for which \(P\) is at instantaneous rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 395, 186, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 395, 423, 414]]<|/det|>
Find the initial acceleration of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 395, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 670, 143, 689]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 670, 420, 689]]<|/det|>
Find the minimum velocity of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 670, 920, 689]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 771, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the distance travelled by \(P\) during the time when its velocity is negative.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(1600\mathrm{kg}\) is pulling a caravan of mass \(800\mathrm{kg}\). The car and the caravan are connected by a light rigid tow-bar. The resistances to the motion of the car and caravan are \(400\mathrm{N}\) and \(250\mathrm{N}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 134, 688, 153]]<|/det|>
The car and caravan are travelling along a straight horizontal road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 161, 198, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 161, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
Given that the car and caravan have a constant speed of \(25 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\), find the power of the car's engine.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 178, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 415, 191, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 414, 920, 448]]<|/det|>
The engine's power is now suddenly increased to \(39\mathrm{kW}\). Find the instantaneous acceleration of the car and caravan and find the tension in the tow-bar.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 432, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 81, 875, 163]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 176, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
As shown in the diagram, particles \(A\) and \(B\) of masses \(2\mathrm{kg}\) and \(3\mathrm{kg}\) respectively are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a small fixed smooth pulley which is attached to the top of two inclined planes. Particle \(A\) is on plane \(P\), which is inclined at an angle of \(10^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. Particle \(B\) is on plane \(Q\), which is inclined at an angle of \(20^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The string is taut, and the two parts of the string are parallel to lines of greatest slope of their respective planes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 271, 146, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 271, 920, 288]]<|/det|>
It is given that plane \(P\) is smooth, plane \(Q\) is rough, and the particles are in limiting equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 301, 655, 320]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of friction between particle \(B\) and plane \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 301, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that both planes are smooth and that the particles are released from rest at the same horizontal level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the time taken until the difference in the vertical height of the particles is \(1 \mathrm{~m}\). [You should assume that this occurs before \(A\) reaches the pulley or \(B\) reaches the bottom of plane \(Q\).] [6]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 75, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
# Additional Page
